title: Billie Eilish didn't think Bury A Friend would be a success
text:
Billie Eilish didn’t think Bury A Friend would be a success (Picture: Getty Images)

Billie Eilish didn’t think her song Bury A Friend would be a success, and boy was she wrong.

The 17-year-old found herself having an in-depth chat with Green Day frontman Billie Joe Armstrong, where she spoke about keeping her songs authentic – even though her fans might not like what they heard.

And it turns out she was shocked to see her single perform so well in the charts, after it landed in the Top 20, as well as taking top spot in the Official Trending Chart.

The young star told her fellow musician: ‘I’ve been surprised people like my music. Because there’s such a world of liking nothing, music that’s not really doing anything.

‘I remember having this conversation with my mum about Bury A Friend. We were like, “Nobody’s gonna give a f***, because the lyrics are, I want to end me.”‘

She added: ‘And I really, honestly did not think anyone would care. That’s why this whole ride has been so weird.’

The duo were interviewing each other for Rolling Stone magazine, and the punk rocker couldn’t help but gush over Billie and her hit.

He told her: ‘That song, you’re talking about death. That’s as real as it gets. That’s real, real stuff.

‘When I was writing music when I was really young, it was always important to me to feel like I’m writing songs that I can sing 20 years later.’

Billie Joe Armstrong is a Billie Eilish fan (Picture: Getty Images)

The 47-year-old explained: ‘A song like Basket Case, it’s a song about losing your mind. As you get older, it gets more and more real. And that’s what creates longevity.’

Following the release of the Bad Guy hitmaker’s latest album, When We All Fall Asleep, Where Do We Go?, Billie became the youngest ever female solo act to top the charts.

At the time she thanked her fans, saying: ‘I appreciate you making WHEN WE ALL FALL ASLEEP, WHERE DO WE GO? the #1 album in the UK so much.

‘We worked really hard on this album. Thank you for the love!!’

At 17 years, three months and 18 days old, Billie overtook Joss Stone – now 31 – as the youngest woman to top the Official Albums Chart.

It was a close call, however, as Joss’ 2004 record Mind, Body & Soul reached Number One when she was 17 years, five months and 28 days old.
